FY 22-23.mission: The RNA Epitranscriptomics and Proteomics Resources (REPR) was created by consolidating the RNA analysis and proteomics capabilities existing at the University at Albany. This specialized resource offers an extensive range of state-of-the-art mass spectrometry instrumentation and know-how. The mission is to capitalize on the extensive expertise in the analysis of RNA, RNA modifications, and proteins involved in RNA metabolism/regulation to benefit both internal and external investigators interested in these types of topics.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​The resource supports also projects involving the analysis of a wide range of biomolecules, metabolites, and small synthetic molecules. In addition to providing full-service analysis, REPR welcomes the opportunity to enter full-fledged partnerships that may involve extensive consulting on experimental design, sample preparation and data interpretation, as well as whole project development and grant writing contributions. Please, contact us to inquire on how we can best help you.
FY 22-23.annualBudget: Budgets is keyed to use, with use billing out  $83,373.75.  These moneys are used to maintian equipment and fund reagents for project use.

FY 22-23.mission: The mission of the New York State Mesonet (NYSM) is to serve the state of New York by providing the best meteorological data, the best products, and the best services possible with the goal of saving lives and property while building a smart weather economy. At its core, the NYSM is a highly dedicated, cross-disciplinary team aspiring to set the worldwide standard of excellence for data quality. With its unique focus on research to operations, preventive maintenance, and state-of-the-art quality control efforts, the NYSM utilizes these high quality weather data to create end products designed to improve forecast accuracy, reduce uncertainty, and mitigate harm.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​The vision of the New York State Mesonet is to become a national center, collaborating with government, academic, and commercial partners, to educate and solve real-world problems in agriculture, emergency management, energy, public health, and transportation, improving the well being and livelihood for all.

FY 22-23.mission: To provide ion beam irradiation and implantation education, training, and services to researchers from UAlbany, other academic insitutions, federal research agencies, and private industry to probe structure of materials, affect modification of structure by and impact of ion irradiation on their physical, chemical, and electronic properties.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​The Ion Beam Laboratory (IBL) strives to remain one of the leading laboratory of its kind in the nation and offer a wide variety of irradiation, measurement, and analysis facilities and services to researchers. The IBL assists its users and partners in advancing the science and technology of biological, chemical, solid state, and electronic materials leading to the growth of new businesses in New York state and the country.
FY 22-23.goal1: ​​To design and install a new vacuum and control system on the Dynamitron accelerator. This will allow the facility to be prepared to meet the needs of the next generation of micro chip research, in addition to the ever more demanding precision required by other research activities.​
FY 22-23.goal2: ​​Increase the use of the facility by outside clients which will increase revenues and IBL participation in a wider range of research efforts. Increase the amount of analysis work done by IBL staff on behalf of outside clients which would also increase revenue. Prepare for the increased usage of the IBL due to the passing of the Chips Act.
FY 22-23.goal3: ​​Design and build a low energy Ion implantation accelerator to service the need of the NASA Genesis project.
FY 22-23.goal4: ​​The successful acquisition of the standard sample.
FY 22-23.actions1: ​​The addition of a second permanent engineer to assist in the redesign and installation efforts. The successful award of a $ 500,00.00 earmark grant to cover the costs.
FY 22-23.actions2: ​​Redesigning the website making it easier for clients to use to access IBL services. Direct marketing efforts performed by IBL staff to increase business.
FY 22-23.actions3: ​​The addition of a second permanent engineer to assist in the design and construction efforts. The successful award of a $ 500,00.00 earmark grant to cover the costs.
FY 22-23.actions4: ​​The successful acquisition of the standard sample.
FY 22-23.metrics1: The success of the project will be measure by a decrease in EM noise in measured data, and a marked increase in vacuum purity.
FY 22-23.metrics2: An increase in revenue for the IBL in these areas.
FY 22-23.metrics3: ​​The successful construction of a functioning accelerator.
FY 22-23.timeframe1: It will take one year after receiving the resources to the completion of the project, it will be possible to assess the success at that time.
FY 22-23.timeframe4: Withing six months of obtaining the sample.

FY 22-23.mission: The Center for Technology in Government at the University at Albany (CTG UAlbany) generates knowledge, develops capabilities, and co-creates technology-enabled innovations with government leaders and organizations to address societal challenges and increase public value.
FY 22-23.vision: To be recognized as a global leader in research excellence that produces practical solutions and innovations in public sector digital transformation.
FY 22-23.annualBudget:
CTG UAlbany’s revenue stream consists of research grants and awards, corporate sponsored projects, and research agreements supported through the Research Foundation, as well as various University at Albany state and municipal MOUs and contract projects. This year, CTG UAlbany will realize $234,166 in IFR revenue from two RF projects and $294,690 from two state-side MOUs and contracts. A budget reduction of $50,000 and a $5,100 transfer to VPRED to cover their telephone/IT expense reduced our state-side revue to $254,690.  In addition, total state overhead paid on these awards will be $17,562 and $44,204, respectively, for a total of $61,766. Finally, fringe on both accounts will be $38,969 and $36,389 respectively, for a total of $75,358. Taking all these factors into account, our net revenue for CTG UAlbany FY 2022-2023 will be $336,633. The remaining revenue helped to support annual operating expenses of $301,812. The expense categories included technical equipment and software, graduate students, temp service and term positions, supplies, service contracts, online and in-person training and conferences, non-project supported travel, state project-related expenses, and any other non-PSR expense needed to operate CTG UAlbany. We do not receive an annual OTPS allocation from the Division of Research, instead we revenue generates on our own to support our OTPS budget. We also received an allocation from Rock College to the PSR account in the amount of $16,000. This was used to cover temp salary expenses on our 900309 IFR account. Our PSR state allocation of $664,650 supported 6.25 FTEs. This year we did not have the Applications Developer position as part of our PSR. The incumbent left the end of the last fiscal year and our attempt to replace them resulted in a failed search. We therefore utilized his line to move the remaining Director of Administration and Finance line over to PSR along with a portion of the CTG Director’s line. Due to the lack of IT support, we invested a much higher percentage of our IFR line to graduate and student assistants who could help fill this critical gap. The savings due to the partial movements of the two lines over to PSR helped to mitigate this cost. 

CTG UAlbany continues to be very strategic with our business development goals and is committed to seeking out new funding opportunities and partnerships. 

This year we submitted two grant proposals totaling $1,385,119 which are currently pending. The first was submitted to the National Science Foundation (NSF) for an Accountable Institutions and Behavior grant entitled, “Accountability in the Age of Artificial Intelligence” in the amount of $749,867. The second was a 3-year grant submitted to the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS) for a National Leadership Grant for Libraries entitled, “Empowering Communities: Public Libraries, Civic Engagement and Artificial Intelligence” in the amount of $635,252.  Residual funds not utilized in this fiscal year will be used next year and in the coming years to help continue support for the two temporary research IFR funded positions mentioned above, including our Researcher in Digital Government, as well as our Program Associate.

FY 22-23.topAchievements1: 1. Successfully Submitted New Research Proposals and Managed Existing Federally and State Funded Research Projects Consistent with our goals, CTG UAlbany developed and submitted two new research proposals, both focused on the topic of artificial intelligence. The first, titled, “AI Impact on Bureaucratic Accountability and Accountability to Citizens” and submitted to the National Science Foundation (NSF) Accountable Institutions and Behavior Program. The second, “Empowering Communities: Public Libraries, Civic Engagement, and Artificial Intelligence was submitted to Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS) National Leadership Grants for Libraries Program. These research proposals not only build on our expertise on digital government but are also aligned with the university’s recent AI initiative, which we consider an important achievement. In addition, we are still successfully implementing and managing existing research projects, very well aligned as well with the university’s research priorities. At the federal level, through a $2.8 million contract from the United States Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), researchers from CTG UAlbany and the College of Emergency Preparedness, Homeland Security and Cybersecurity (CEHC) are developing a Message Design Dashboard system for FEMA to help emergency managers write more effective messages for public alert and warning. Similarly, CTG UAlbany and the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences are collaborating in a research project funded by a five-year $1,494,805 grant from the National Science Foundation (NSF) to help improve emergency communications and preparedness in rural areas in upstate New York. At the state level, with total funding to date of $636,834 from the New York State Board of Elections (NYS BOE), CTG UAlbany, leading a multi institution team with UAlbany CEHC, Albany Law School Government Law Center and industry experts IDC, started the third of three projects focused on the security and resiliency of technical and organizational elections infrastructure in NYS. Further, with total funding of $410,417 from New York State, CTG UAlbany completed a six year project that we led with the City of Schenectady on behalf of the Cities of Gloversville, Amsterdam, Troy, and Cortland. The project resulted in the development of the C.O.D.E., a data sharing platform designed to identify problem actors (landlords, LLCS, agents) so that local governments can inform their blight reduction strategies. Towards the conclusion of the project, CTG UAlbany successfully transitioned the role we played in the project to the City of Schenectady to help ensure the ongoing operation and growth of the C.O.D.E. to other local governments in New York State.
FY 22-23.topAchievements2: 2. Maintained and Grew CTG UAlbany Recognition’s as a Global Leader in Digital Transformation in Government Research by Serving as Invited Speakers at and Playing Leadership Roles in International Conferences, Meetings, and other Engagements We accomplished important milestones in terms of visibility and expansion of our international network by accepting a mix of international keynote invitations (for example, during the Open Government Week in Peru, the First Innovation and Smart Government Conference (ISGOV) in Mexico, or the Smart City Expo in Spain). In addition, we participated in several international panels and conferences presenting our research and meeting several of our dissemination goals. We also served in leadership roles in a number of the leading international digital government and public administration conferences to include 23th Annual International Conference on Digital Government Research (dg.o 2022), IFIP EGOV 2022, The Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences (HICSS), and the International Research Society for Public Management (IRSPM).
FY 22-23.topAchievements3: 3. Developed a Technology Innovation to Support Government Services, which could be potentially commercialized SUNY Technology Accelerator Fund (TAF) Community Asset Tracker Application New developments have been made to the Community Asset Tracker application, for which CTG UAlbany is using a $50,000 SUNY Technology Accelerator Fund investment. The Community Asset Tracker uses a mobile artificial intelligence driven sensor network to track government assets. CTG UAlbany is using the CAT and our efforts to help communities evaluate and implement the system to improve government operations and services. Work in this respect has been started with the City of Schenectady. The progress made in the development of the CAT is an accomplishment that will help us submit a new research proposal to the NSF’s Smart and Connected Communities Program in the next few months, therefore contributing to the achievement of some of our research goals. Further, CTG UAlbany’s aim is to commercialize the technology through licensing to a startup or existing company, expanding its reach. And, therefore, also contributing to the university’s economic development goals.
FY 22-23.topAchievements4: 4. Engaged Students in Research and Practice Projects CTG UAlbany provides students with valuable research experience working on projects with CTG researchers, government partners, and mix of federal, state, and international research funders. For 2022-2023, CTG UAlbany trained approximately 16 undergraduate, graduate, and PhD students and provided approximately $196,427 in salaries and tuition from external RF awards and State MOUs. The training provided helped students to contribute to CTG Albany’s research agenda in a variety of ways and, therefore, this is an important accomplishment in terms of our research goals.
FY 22-23.topAchievements5: 5. Developed a New UAlbany Faculty Fellows Program At the request of the new UAlbany Vice President for Research and Economic Development, CTG UAlbany developed and launched a formal faculty fellows program to help facilitate meaningful research collaborations among UAlbany faculty researchers around the topics of information and technology in government. This program has been one of our major accomplishments, not only in terms of putting it together, but also in terms of increasing our visibility within the University, making new connections and leveraging opportunities for further interdisciplinary and meaningful research, well aligned with the University’s priorities. We successfully increased our number of faculty fellows from 3 to 23 representing 10 different departments at UAlbany. In addition, we held our first CTG Faculty Fellows Kick off Meeting in February 2023.

FY 22-23.actionsImplemented1: We submitted two research proposals to federal agencies and continued to work on five federal and state funded research projects.
FY 22-23.actionsImplemented3: CTG UAlbany provides students with valuable research experience working on projects with CTG researchers, government partners, and mix of federal, state, and international research funders. For 2022-2023, CTG UAlbany trained approximately 20 undergraduate, graduate, and PhD students and post doc and provided approximately $196,427 in salaries and tuition from external RF awards and State MOUs.
FY 22-23.actionsImplemented4: Produced 23 academic and practitioner reports, articles, and papers.
FY 22-23.actionsImplemented5: Delivered approximately 30 keynotes, panel moderators, workshops, and paper presentations and served on almost 60 advisory boards and committees.
FY 22-23.noteworthyResults2: Ramon, Mila, and Theresa continue to teach courses within the nationally-ranked Government Information Strategy and Management (GISM) concentration at Rockefeller College of Public Affairs & Policy and have teaching and mentoring partnerships with Rockefeller College and the College of Emergency Preparedness, Homeland Security and Cybersecurity for students pursuing a Ph.D. in Information Science.
FY 22-23.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: National and state funding priorities are aligned with several of CTG UAlbany’s topics and areas of expertise, which may result in more or larger funded research proposals and, therefore, increased revenue. Some of these priorities revolve around the topics of artificial intelligence, security and resiliency of critical infrastructure, data analytics, emergency preparedness and response, cybersecurity, and digital inclusion. Potential future projects may take advantage of this opportunity. First, regarding artificial intelligence, in January 2023 we submitted a proposal to the National Science Foundation Accountable Institutions and Behavior program that will explore the changes to public vertical and horizontal accountability brought about by AI-based automated decision-making processes. Second, in March 2023 we submitted a research proposal to the Institute of Museum and Library Sciences aimed to understand the role of public libraries in fostering inclusive civic engagement in all aspects of artificial intelligence. At the time of writing we are preparing a third proposal (due in September 2023) for the National Science Foundation Science of Organizations program that will study the impact of the use of AI systems in the internal organizational dynamics of public organizations. Second, on the topic of elections infrastructure, CTG UAlbany led the fourth funded project with the New York State Board of Elections. This project is in alignment with UAlbany’s strategic goal of security and resiliency and cybersecurity as we help state and county leaders envision a more secure technical infrastructure for voter registrations and all elections related functions. Calls from federal agencies are increasingly interdisciplinary and CTG UAlbany is in a unique position to contribute to the socio-technical aspects of information and technology in government. The potential projects above are also examples of how CTG UAlbany is contributing to important topics from an interdisciplinary perspective. UAlbany’s prioritization (and therefore available support) of commercialization efforts is also an opportunity for CTG UAlbany. Given the type of work we do, several of our projects’ results and outcomes may be commercialize, which could potentially increase revenue, but also benefit society as a whole. This particularly applies to our SUNY Technology Accelerator Fund Community Asset Tracker (CAT) project. We currently are working with the City of Schenectady to deploy and test the CAT sensors throughout the City. In addition, we are planning to submit a new research proposal focused on the CAT to the NSF Smart and Connected Communities (S&CC) program by spring 2024. The hiring initiative that is bringing to UAlbany 27 new faculty with a focus on AI in multiple disciplines may also be an opportunity for CTG UAlbany and its new faculty fellows program. New faculty across the university may be invited to be part of our fellows program, which may result in higher research productivity from an inter-disciplinary perspective (more research proposals submitted to federal agencies, more articles in journals from diverse disciplines, more conference papers, etc.) and, therefore, in strengthening the focus on AI as a distinctive feature of UAlbany.
FY 22-23.bigChallenges: The number of competitors in the form of other academic research centers outside of UAlbany and private sector consultants is growing. More of these organizations have a focus on digital transformation research and applications (CTG UAlbany’s area of expertise) and in particular on the topic of artificial intelligence, although their interest in these topics is often linked to the available opportunities rather than to real expertise/experience on those topics. In this respect, they compete with us in terms of state funding, federal research dollars, and foundation funding. There are university imposed financial constraints, which impact our ability to attract and retain talent which in turn affects our ability to generate knowledge, build capability, and disseminate information in a sustainable way. Long term positions have turned into short term and soft funded positions that result in high rotation and the need for retraining. Other positions, such as the Communications Manager, have completely disappeared, hindering our capacity to efficiently disseminate our work nationally and internationally, as we have in the past, and gain visibility for both CTG UAlbany and the university as a whole. This creates an ongoing challenge. Finding PhD students to work in our projects has become harder than before. Given that we do not exactly know when a project may receive funding, hiring students becomes a last minute task. As a result, students are often not available when we need them and when they are, further challenges may make hiring them difficult. For example, they may not have research interests within the field of digital government or they may be 1st or 2nd year students, with little experience and research independence. Further, inconsistencies with stipends (amounts and specific appointment dates) across departments for PhD students continue to be an important challenge in this respect. University-wide staff challenges are also impacting the work CTG UAlbany does. In particular, the staff shortage that Sponsored Programs is experiencing poses challenges to our own research administration (pre and post award support). The lack of response and the lack of familiarity with the type of work and the type of research projects we do are only two of the negative consequences of this staff shortage. In this respect, the type of support we used to get in the past from Sponsored Programs seems to be very limited or even no longer available. It seems that some people perceive that UAlbany research institutes, centers, and laboratories (ICLs) are making limited contributions to UAlbany. We believe this is due to a lack of indicators that allow UAlbany research institutes, centers, and laboratories (ICLs) to be assessed based on multiple dimensions. These dimensions include externally funded projects, but also publications, citations, service to the community, student engagement, and internationalization, among other important criteria. One potential way to achieve this could be to gather information from professional researchers and other staff members similar to the FAR used for faculty members. This would also help to highlight the contributions of ICLs to different university strategic priorities as well as to designations such as R1, Public Engagement Institution, etc. Although funding agencies encourage an interdisciplinary approach to address societal problems, most call for proposals and subsequent reviews are focused on the technical components of research topics. CTG UAlbany’s socio-technical approach to information and technology in government requires us to partner with other organizations and colleagues (who may mainly have a technical approach) which expands our networks, but it is also costly and time consuming. These partnerships are highly valued but require significant resources to build and maintain.
FY 22-23.strategicSuggestions: Continue to invest in support for proposal development and pre and post award support in general. Also, we think that it is very important to expand the staff and expertise of the UAlbany technology development office. Resources and expertise in this area are critical to helping CTG UAlbany and other researchers at UAlbany determine if and how their research findings can be protected and commercialized.

FY 23-24.mission: The Center for Technology in Government at the University at Albany (CTG UAlbany) generates knowledge, develops capabilities, and co-creates technology-enabled innovations with government leaders and organizations to address societal challenges and increase public value.
FY 23-24.vision: To be recognized as a global leader in research excellence that produces practical solutions and innovations in public sector digital transformation.
FY 23-24.annualBudget: CTG UAlbany’s revenue stream consists of research grants and awards, corporate sponsored projects, and research agreements supported through the Research Foundation, as well as various University at Albany state and municipal MOUs and contract projects. This year, CTG UAlbany will realize $234,166 in IFR revenue from two RF projects and $294,690 from two state-side MOUs and contracts. A budget reduction of $50,000 and a $5,100 transfer to VPRED to cover their telephone/IT expense reduced our state-side revue to $254,690. In addition, total state overhead paid on these awards will be $17,562 and $44,204, respectively, for a total of $61,766. Finally, fringe on both accounts will be $38,969 and $36,389 respectively, for a total of $75,358. Taking all these factors into account, our net revenue for CTG UAlbany FY 2022-2023 will be $336,633. The remaining revenue helped to support annual operating expenses of $301,812. The expense categories included technical equipment and software, graduate students, temp service and term positions, supplies, service contracts, online and in-person training and conferences, non-project supported travel, state project-related expenses, and any other non-PSR expense needed to operate CTG UAlbany. We do not receive an annual OTPS allocation from the Division of Research, instead we revenue generate on our own to support our OTPS budget. We also received an allocation from Rock College to the PSR account in the amount of $16,000. This was used to cover temp salary expenses on our 900309 IFR account. Our PSR state allocation of $664,650 supported 6.25 FTEs. This year we did not have the Applications Developer position as part of our PSR. The incumbent left the end of the last fiscal year and our attempt to replace them resulted in a failed search. We therefore utilized his line to move the remaining Director of Administration and Finance line over to PSR along with a portion of the CTG Director’s line. Due to the lack of IT support, we invested a much higher percentage of our IFR line to graduate and student assistants who could help fill this critical gap. The savings due to the partial movements of the two lines over to PSR helped to mitigate this cost. CTG UAlbany continues to be very strategic with our business development goals and is committed to seeking out new funding opportunities and partnerships. This year we submitted two grant proposals totaling $1,385,119 which are currently pending. The first was submitted to the National Science Foundation (NSF) for an Accountable Institutions and Behavior grant entitled, “Accountability in the Age of Artificial Intelligence” in the amount of $749,867. The second was a 3-year grant submitted to the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS) for a National Leadership Grant for Libraries entitled, “Empowering Communities Public Libraries, Civic Engagement and Artificial Intelligence” in the amount of $635,252. Residual funds not utilized in this fiscal year will be used next year and in the coming years to help continue support for the two temporary research IFR funded positions mentioned above, including our Researcher in Digital Government, as well as our Program Associate.

FY 22-23.mission: CSDA's mission is to facilitate and organize population research and education of the highest caliber. It seeks to accomplish this mission by creating a stimulating and cohesive intellectual environment conducive to the development of multidisciplinary population scholarship, particularly on the Center's signature themes of spatial inequalities and vulnerable populations. Key areas of research include health and health disparities, immigration, risks to youth and adolescents, spatial inequalities and migration, American families, and social resources and vulnerabilities of the elderly.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​Our vision is to increase our funding portfolio, forge linkages with other units on campus that don't know about CSDA, attract students from underrepresented minority groups to engage in population-based research, and conduct strategic planning to solidify our larger vision moving forward.
FY 22-23.annualBudget: Our half-time employee, Jin-Wook Lee, who we share with the Lewis Mumford Center (AVAIL), is sorely underpaid. We would like to pay him over-time via the RF if we get funding in the future and would like to discuss that possibility with you.

FY 22-23.otherActivities:
Zai Liang, named Distinguished Research Professor
Youqin Huang, won President's Excellence Award in Research and Creative Activities
FY 22-23.topAchievements1: Our research associate Betty Lin secured a $3 million R01 grant from the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development to investigate the social and environmental causes of black maternal and child health disparities. The funding is from the Population Dynamics Branch (PDB) of NICHD. PDB is the branch that puts the RFA for the population center infrastructural grant that CSDA has acquired in the past. By having Betty Lin's R01 in this portfolio will make CSDA competitive for future center infrastructural funding. We plan to apply for funding in 2025 rather than this year (2023) so that we can acquire for 1-2 more R01s in the PDB funding portfolio.
FY 22-23.topAchievements2: The productivity of CSDA associates is significant. Our associates published 188 scholarly journal articles during the past academic year and 60% of those publications were in peer-reviewed journals in the first quartiles of their disciplines. Collectively, our associates applied for $17.7 million in extramural funding in 2022-2023. They won awards totalling $9.8 million. With seed funding available in the upcoming year through ISHE, I have no doubt that CSDA associates will capitalize on that funding and develop larger-scale grants. In the past when we had seed funding through our infrastructural grant, that is exactly what happened. Moreover, our associates are much more successful in bringing in federal funding than other social science units on campus (i.e. CEMHD, CHSR).
FY 22-23.topAchievements3: CSDA will participate in the NextGenPop program at Cornell in June, which is a program designed to support the training and mentoring of undergraduates from underrepresented backgrounds into the field of demography -- see https//cpc.cornell.edu/demography-training/nextgenpop-recruiting-the-next-generation-of-population-research-scholars/ CSDA is mentioned at the bottom.
FY 22-23.topAchievements4: We had three successful colloquiums this year on 1) "Emergency Department Closures and Mortality" by Dr. Pinka Chatterji, Professor of Economics, UAlbany 2) "Places, Policies, and Population Health Drug Overdoses, COVID-19, and Long-term Mortality Trends in Rural America," By Dr. Shannon M. Monnat, Professor of Sociology; Lerner Chair in Public Health Promotion and Population Health; Director, Center for Policy Research, Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs, Syracuse University (also UAlbany PhD alumnus) 3) "From Chinatown to Every Town How Chinese Immigrant Entrepreneurs Have Expanded Restaurant Business in the United States," by Dr. Zai Liang, Distinguished Research Professor of Sociology, UAlbany
FY 22-23.topAchievements5: We had raised money in honor of previous CSDA Director, Dr. Stewart E. Tolnay, to make an award in his name every year. The fundraising was done to commerorate the 40th anniversary of CSDA in 2021. This year, we presented the first recipient of the Stewart E. Tolnay Outstanding Graduate Student Paper Award to doctoral student Han Liu.
FY 22-23.goal1: ​​Our first priority is to increase our funding portfolio, with an emphasis on applying for grants in the Population Dynamics Branch (PDB) of NICHD.  Expanding funding in the latter agency will increase our ability to be successful in being funding by a future center grant from NICHD.
FY 22-23.goal2: ​​Our second main goal is to continue to forge linkages with other units on campus that either do not know about CSDA or have started to know about CSDA. We are particularly interested in continuing to develop capacity for our research associates to engage in research that links climate change and disasters to the demographics that they are currently studying and that are CSDA’s themes – health, migration, and spatial inequalities. None of our CSDA associates are currently from the College of Emergency Preparedness, Homeland Security, and Cybersecurity (CEHC) or from the Department of Atmospheric and Environmental Sciences. However, the research that is conducted in both units is focused on disasters and climate change, which has implications for all of the main foci of CSDA. We would also like to forge linkages with the Department of Computer Science and College of Engineering.
FY 22-23.goal3: ​​Our third priority is to explore ways to attract students, particularly underrepresented minorities, to engage in population-based research, enhance student experiences of those already engaged in population-based research, and ultimately, through the former endeavors, grow a workforce to assist CSDA associates.
FY 22-23.actions1: ​​ To achieve this goal, we will 1) have a colloquium series this year to showcase successful NICHD grantees from other universities and their research; 2)  organize meetings around each of our core themes -- 1) population health; 2) immigration and internal migration; and 3) spatial inequalities -- with our faculty associates working in those areas to identify opportunities for future collaboration as it fits with the Population Dynamics Branch of PDB.
FY 22-23.actions2: ​​1) Host meetings to facilitate connections between our CSDA associates and researchers on campus outside of CSDA that work on climate change and disasters and/or social networks/computing. 2) Invite key stakeholders like Chris Thorncroft and Eric Stern to be on our Advisory Board. 3) Continue to explore funding mechanisms to bring collaborations across these units. At a meeting I recently attended of the Association of Population Centers, we were informed that a working group at NICHD is discussing potential funding options linking climate change and health.
FY 22-23.actions3: ​​To achieve this goal, we will 1) identify our associates who are working on research with undergraduates; 2) make CSDA activities more visible to undergraduates at UAlbany by encouraging their participation in our colloquium series and by holding virtual events surrounding Census 2020; and 3) network with other departments who do not know about CSDA but whose students could be of great value to CSDA associates (e.g., data science, statistics, and information science)
FY 22-23.metrics1: We will measure our success by gauging the increase in applications for funding to NICHD and other funding agencies.
FY 22-23.metrics2: 1) Number of meetings2) Number of attendees at meetings3) Number of collaborative publications4) Number of collaborative grants5) Number of new CSDA associates from ASRC/CEHC and other departments
FY 22-23.metrics3: ​​Our success will be based upon our ability to attract undergraduate students to participate in our events; and to involve more undergraduate and graduate students of color in the research of CSDA associates.
FY 22-23.actionsImplemented1: CSDA Director Samantha Friedman nominated several productive scholars on campus to join CSDA as research associates. Their nominations were approved by the Executive Committee. We will be nominating Paul Morgan to be a CSDA associate as soon as he arrives in Albany in mid-June.
FY 22-23.actionsImplemented2: CSDA Director Samantha Friedman nominated several productive scholars on campus from different schools/departments to join CSDA as research associates. Their nominations were approved by the Executive Committee. These researchers include Kai Zhang from Environmental Health Sciences who does work on climate change and strengthens our expertise in this area along with Shao Lin and Samantha Friedman. We also brought in Betty Lin from Psychology who adds significant strength in the area of maternal health, which is a key area of focus within NICHD. We will be nominating Paul Morgan to be a CSDA associate as soon as he arrives in Albany in mid-June.
FY 22-23.actionsImplemented3: We advertised a work-study position in the Fall of 2022 to attract students to work for CSDA, but there were few applicants. CSDA Director Samantha Friedman will be participating in the NextGenPop program at Cornell in June 2023. The program is designed to build a pipeline to bring talented undergraduates of color into the field of population sciences. Her participation at the two-week program will bring visibility to CSDA among this very talented group of undergraduates, which will hopefully result in more applications of students of color to doctoral programs of departments affliliated with CSDA (e.g., sociology, economics, public health departments).
FY 22-23.noteworthyResults1: One of the new CSDA Associates, Betty Lin, has a $3 million grant in the NICHD portfolio and specifically in the Population Dynamics Branch (PDB). Paul Morgan also has funding at NICHD for $80,250 that will expire in FY 2024. In the past, he has had larger funded grants from PDB. Bringing these researchers into CSDA as research associates is a significant gain for CSDA's competitiveness in future rounds of funding for the infrastructural grant.
FY 22-23.noteworthyResults2: The biggest gains were bringing new, incredibly productive scholars into CSDA as associates who work in key areas that are important to NICHD.
FY 22-23.noteworthyResults3: We found it very difficult to attract undergraduate students to work for CSDA, whereas in previous years, we had an easier time.
FY 22-23.changes1: In the upcoming year, we will have meetings among our associates to strategize how they can apply for ISHE seed grant funding to get grants in the NICHD PDB portfolio. This will boost our competitiveness for the population infrastructural grant in 2025.
FY 22-23.changes2: One of the reasons we did not formalize our Advisory Board is because we were waiting for the establishment of ISHE. Now that ISHE has been established, we will finalize our invitations for our Advisory Board and include either Chris Thorncroft and/or Eric Stern. The establishment of ISHE will also greatly facilitate collaborations among new research teams because of their seed-funding mechanism.
FY 22-23.changes3: Next year at the Showcase Day, CSDA will have a table at the event to showcase to undergraduates what we do and potentially get them involved and connected with our research associates.
FY 22-23.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: To obtain an infrastructural center grant in the future and to apply in 2025.
FY 22-23.bigChallenges: CSDA has no administrative or research staff, and we have no seed funding as we did before 2018.
FY 22-23.resourceNeeds: Seed funding; administrative staff; grant writer(s); and staff to conduct basic data cleaning/statistical analyses -- this could be 1-2 GA lines.
FY 22-23.strategicSuggestions: We hope that the VPRED and Dr. Paul Morgan will move CSDA under the umbrella of ISHE so that our associates have access to the infrastructure being developed at ISHE in terms of the grant writer and other administrative support via the RF. Twenty-four of our CSDA associates are already affiliates of CEMHD, the Engaged Researchers group, or Center for Aging and Policy Studies (CAPS) affliates. Housing CSDA within ISHE would avoid redundancy for faculty and allow UAlbany to consolidate its resources around social science/public health research on minority health disparities. Everyone at UAlbany wins that way in my opinion. CSDA associates will definitely be applying for the seed funding that will be available through ISHE because it is precisely the resources that they need to get preliminary results to write effective R01 grants.
FY 22-23.otherthoughts: The VPRED should use this AI initiative to form a data analytics center via ITS that houses data support for faculty. I'm struck by the fact that there is no consolidation of resources at an R1 university to help faculty with data programming and analytics support. There should be free services and then they should be purchased via grant support. They could be GA lines for talented graduate students in data science, information technology, sociology, engineering, public health, etc.

FY 23-24.mission: ​​CSDA's mission is to facilitate and organize population research and education of the highest caliber. It seeks to accomplish this mission by creating a stimulating and cohesive intellectual environment conducive to the development of multidisciplinary population scholarship, particularly on the Center's signature themes of spatial inequalities and vulnerable populations.  Key areas of research include health and health disparities, immigration, risks to youth and adolescents, spatial inequalities and migration, American families, and social resources and vulnerabilities of the elderly.
FY 23-24.vision: ​​Our vision is to increase our funding portfolio, forge linkages with other units on campus that don't know about CSDA, attract students from underrepresented minority groups to engage in population-based research, and conduct strategic planning to solidify our larger vision moving forward.
FY 23-24.goal1: ​​Our first priority is to increase our funding portfolio, with an emphasis on applying for grants in the Population Dynamics Branch (PDB) of NICHD. Expanding funding in the latter agency will increase our ability to be successful in being funding by a future center grant from NICHD.
FY 23-24.goal2: Our second main goal is to continue to forge linkages with other units on campus that either do not know about CSDA or have started to know about CSDA. We are particularly interested in continuing to develop capacity for our research associates to engage in research that links climate change and disasters to the demographics that they are currently studying and that are CSDA’s themes – health, migration, and spatial inequalities. None of our CSDA associates are currently from the College of Emergency Preparedness, Homeland Security, and Cybersecurity (CEHC) or from the Department of Atmospheric and Environmental Sciences. However, the research that is conducted in both units is focused on disasters and climate change, which has implications for all of the main foci of CSDA. We would also like to forge linkages with the Department of Computer Science and College of Engineering. We also want to forge linkages with newly hired AI faculty.
FY 23-24.goal3: Our third goal is to explore ways to attract students, particularly underrepresented minorities, to engage in population-based research, enhance student experiences of those already engaged in population-based research, and ultimately, through the former endeavors, grow a workforce to assist CSDA associates.
FY 23-24.actions1: ​​To achieve this goal, we will 1) have a colloquium series this year to showcase successful NICHD grantees from other universities and their research; 2) organize meetings around each of our core themes -- a) population health; b) immigration and internal migration; and c) spatial inequalities -- with our faculty associates working in those areas to identify opportunities for future collaboration as it fits with the Population Dynamics Branch of PDB; and 3) based upon those meetings, we will encourage faculty to apply for seed funding via ISHE so that they can advance their work and have preliminary results to include in an R01 application.
FY 23-24.actions2: 1) Host meetings to facilitate connections between our CSDA associates and researchers on campus outside of CSDA that work on climate change and disasters; social networks/computing; and AI. 2) Invite key stakeholders like Chris Thorncroft and Eric Stern to be on our Advisory Board. 3) Continue to explore funding mechanisms to bring collaborations across these units.
FY 23-24.actions3: To achieve this goal, we will 1) identify our associates who are working on research with undergraduates; 2) make CSDA activities more visible to undergraduates at UAlbany by encouraging their participation in our colloquium series and by holding virtual events surrounding Census 2020; and 3) network with other departments who do not know about CSDA but whose students could be of great value to CSDA associates (e.g., data science, statistics, and information science).
FY 23-24.metrics1: We will measure our success by gauging the increase in applications for funding to NICHD and other funding agencies.
FY 23-24.metrics2: 1) Number of meetings; 2) Number of attendees at meetings; 3) Number of collaborative publications; 4) Number of collaborative grants; 5) Number of new CSDA associates from ASRC/CEHC and other departments with new AI faculty hires.
FY 23-24.metrics3: Our success will be based upon our ability to attract undergraduate students to participate in our events; and to involve more undergraduate and graduate students of color in the research of CSDA associates.

FY 22-23.mission: The Center for Human Services Research is dedicated to developing empirically based knowledge to improve the design and delivery of services that address social issues and meet community needs. We conduct evaluation research and design information systems to inform policymakers and service providers across a broad spectrum of fields. The Center for Human Services Research values integrity in its research and is dedicated to providing timely, accurate, and non-biased information to guide best practice in the human services.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​To be the leading university-based research center in the nation that provides leaders and practitioners with empirically based knowledge and technological innovations to create a better world.

FY 22-23.topAchievements1: CHSR completed a needs assessment of WIC (the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children) services in New York State for Hunger Solutions NY and the NYS DOH. WIC is a program for nutrition of low-income pregnant, breastfeeding, and postpartum women, infants, and children under the age of five by providing nutritious foods, information on healthy eating, breastfeeding promotion and support, and referrals to health care. Nationally and statewide, WIC services are underutilized, with only about half of those eligible using the program. This intensive assessment included extensive analyses of secondary data from the American Community Survey and from DOH itself to identify areas and demographics of relatively higher rates of WIC eligibility and lower WIC utilization, for use in future targeting and marketing efforts, as well as primary data collection and analysis (surveys of WIC participants and eligible non-participants, focus groups with WIC participants and eligible non-participants, and a survey of WIC local agency staff) to evaluate their understanding of WIC services and eligibility, successes in using WIC, barriers and challenges to using and maintaining WIC, and recommendations for future program implementation.
FY 22-23.topAchievements2: CHSR created a Role Definition Matrix to better define performance expectations for each of the three main research positions within the Center. This matrix has helped clarify the level and amount of work expected at each role (e.g., more directed to more independent and higher-level), and guided supervisory conversations about performance issues, professional development, and promotion. Most recently, the matrix was used to support annual performance evaluations by allowing staff and supervisors to categorize the work performed and identify areas of especially strong or weak performance.
FY 22-23.topAchievements3: In partnership with the Empire Justice Center and Pro Bono NY, CHSR was awarded a NYS Office of Victim Services Victims of Crime Assistance Act (VOCA) grant. This award will support CHSR’s work on the Crime Victims Legal Network website (https://crimevictimshelpny.org/), which helps victims of crime connect with legal help, including knowing their rights, finding legal services, obtaining victim compensation. In this current grant, CHSR will focus on expanding content on teen dating violence, bullying, and elder victims of crime.
FY 22-23.topAchievements4: CHSR completed a new Tableau dashboard, visualizing the history of performance reporting for Healthy Families New York, a voluntary home visiting program aimed at reducing child maltreatment by building positive parent-child relationships. As part of our ongoing evaluation, CHSR undertakes a series of fidelity and outcome reporting twice each year, reporting on program’s adherence to model specifications and implementation of expected activities in the past six months. These data are used to identify system-wide challenges, programs needing additional support, and programs who are not implementing the program as expected or needed. The dashboard shows performance history on each of 15 items, over 15 reporting cycles (about 7 years), for each of 45 programs. Performance is shown relative to the target performance and to the HFNY state average performance. The dashboards have been helpful to program and OCFS staff in determining whether low performance at a program or on an item is isolated to a particular cycle, is part of a history of low performance, or actually represents an improvement from previous cycles though still with room to grow.
FY 22-23.topAchievements5: CHSR has published two research briefs in the past year. These briefs are meant to help communicate CHSR’s work and program importance to a broader audience. The Genesee-Orleans-Wyoming Opioid Task Force Report summarizes the impact of efforts to increase the number of individuals trained to administer Naloxone in the tri-county area, demonstrating huge increases in trainees as well as improvements in knowledge and self-efficacy due to training. The Crime Victims Legal Network brief explains how researchers and practitioners worked together to develop the Victim Compensation Tool, a part of the CVLN website. CHSR has also joined UAlbany’s Scholars Archive and have posted these briefs to our page there.

FY 22-23.changes1: Due to unexpected staffing and role changes, internal QA Lead was not designated in the past year. CHSR will plan to designate such a lead this upcoming year, and to implement QA monitoring for further projects.
FY 22-23.changes2: No grants that included new Tableau dashboards have yet been awarded. We will continue to include this component in future applications, as appropriate.
FY 22-23.changes3: DMAC's funding status at UAlbany was not clear until the second half of the year, at which point project staff were engaged in other funded activities and could not immediately resume such work. Since the funding allocated will be extended for another fiscal year, CHSR will use this time to work with UAlbany leadership to ensure that DMAC services are filling a campus need and are utilized to the full extent possible.
FY 22-23.changes5: No article submissions to peer-reviewed journals were made in the past year. However, several article drafts are currently "in the works," and staff hope to be able to submit them soon. CHSR will continue to work to try to "buy out" staff time to support such activities. CHSR will also continue to work to explore other avenues for sharing our work and results ith the broader research community.
FY 22-23.bigChallenges: Support for work requiring HIPAA security and higher-level ITS support has been lacking at UAlbany. Staff work on "scholarly activities" requires time away from more immediate contract deliverable work. Uncertainty about certain projects' funding has made future planning difficult, making us more reactive than proactive. CHSR website is outdated, suppressing potential external contact and communication.
FY 22-23.resourceNeeds: University ITS support. Continued funding for DMAC.
FY 22-23.strategicSuggestions: University support for non-faculty research staff toward time to write grants, develop articles for publication.

FY 22-23.mission: The mission of the Center for Functional Genomics is to develop expertise on new and developing genomic technologies that advance and improve the understanding of biology. As part of its mission, the CFG maintains core competencies in genomics, epitranscriptomics, epigenetics and bioinformatics.

FY 22-23.unit: Center for Elimination of Minority Health Disparities
FY 22-23.mission: The mission of the Center for the Elimination of Minority Health Disparities (CEMHD) is to contribute to the elimination of minority health disparities in the smaller cities and towns of New York State. CEMHD’s activities focus on three major interrelated areas, in the service of contributing to the elimination of minority health disparities community engagement, fostering health disparities research, and supporting the development of new health disparities scholars.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​The Center for the Elimination of Minority Health Disparities (CEMHD), is a collaborative effort focusing on minority health disparities in the smaller cities and towns of New York. Home to a 2016 NIMHD S21 Health Disparities Endowment Grant, a 2009 NIMHD P20 Exploratory Center of Excellence, and a 2004 NIMHD R24 EXPORT Center, CEMHD works toward eliminating health disparities by developing capacity in faculty at the University at Albany and partnering with community groups to identify their health concerns and the sources of disparities, and strategies to alleviate them. CEMHD is a partnership among community groups, hospitals, state and county health departments, the State of New York and the University at Albany. CEMHD's focus on minorities and under-served populations in the smaller cities and towns of Upstate New York is premised upon the notion that health disparities found in these areas differ from those in the larger cities, and that the appropriate solutions will also differ. Since most of the research on minority health disparities, and the programs that have resulted from it, has focused on populations in large cities, relatively little is known about the distinct causes of poorer health among minorities in smaller cities. Therefore, another reason for our geographical emphasis is to fill in a gap in the research.

President’s Award for Exemplary Public Engagement
Professor Janine M. Jurkowski - CEMHD Associate
FY 22-23.topAchievements1: Doctoral training a. New admissions to the Fellowship program were paused for Fall 2022 to ensure the financial stability of the program as it transitioned from combined University and Endowment revenue support to being wholly sustained by the Endowment. The full cohort currently stands at nine Fellows, including four S21-supported, and five supported by the Hearst Foundations grant. All of the S21-supported HDTFs (n=5) who began in fall of 2019, 2020, and 2021 have been retained through the current academic year, with the exception of one Fellow who elected to pause his graduate studies after receiving his master’s degree in order to return to field work in his community. In addition, the two fellows supported by Hearst Foundations that entered in 2020 have been retained, as have the three Hearst supported Fellows who entered in fall 2021. Two Fellows who began in Fall 2017 successfully defended their dissertations and had their degrees conferred, as did one Fellow who began in 2018. A second Fellow who began in 2018 defended her dissertation in January 2023 and will have her degree conferred in May 2023. b. The Fellows’ professional accomplishments are too numerous to list here in their entirety. The Fellows have cumulatively published 95 articles in peer-reviewed journals as well as presented their research at national and international conferences. They have also participated in community minority health task forces to develop organizational and operational skills as community-engaged health disparities researchers. Seven Fellows have graduated and now hold positions that include Director of Health Equity Research and Programs at the SUNY Upstate Medical University, Cancer Prevention Research Fellow at the National Cancer Institute, Postdoctoral Fellow in mental health equity research at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital, and tenure track assistant professor of criminal justice at Temple University.
FY 22-23.topAchievements2: Increasing the number of and diversity of health disparities scholars at UAlbany. a. The search for a preeminent scholar to lead the University’s efforts in health disparities has successfully concluded. Dr. Paul Morgan, an internationally recognized scholar of health and educational disparities, will direct a newly formed Institute for Social and Health Equity (ISHE) which will serve as the hub for expanded health equity research activities, as well as home to the CEMHD.
FY 22-23.topAchievements3: Training faculty researchers, community members and leaders, HDTFs and their mentors in health disparities research by hosting events that expose participants to the latest developments in the field, and bring people together to share ideas, and gain expertise and support. a. In April 2023, CEMHD hosted the fourth President’s forum entitled “Community Engagement in the Achievement of Health Equity” virtually (click here www.albany.edu/healthdisparitiesforum). The keynote speech was delivered by Dr. Eliseo J. Perez-Stabe, “Community Engaged Research Pathway to Reducing Disparities.” Dr. Perez-Stable is the Director of the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities. There were 127 attendees, including Community partners, government officials, researchers, faculty, professional staff, postdoctoral associates, and students. A panel discussion followed the keynote, including faculty engaged in community-based research and their partners from community organizations. b. In February and March, the CEMHD presented two noted authorities on health equity research as the latest events in its contributions to the Race and Health speaker series co-sponsored by CEMHD, the Office of the President, and the Division for Research and Economic Development. These two talks were also supported by University Auxiliary Services and open to the public. Dr. Jennifer D. Roberts and Dr. Dána-Ain Davis gave powerful presentations enthusiastically received by audiences of over 100 people including members of the University community as well as participants from New York State’s Capital Region and beyond. Dr. Roberts’ talk entitled “I Can’t Breathe” Environmental Racism in the United States” explored the historical and contemporary inequities that stem from structural racism within the United States through an examination of built, social and natural environments. Dr. Jennifer D. Roberts is an Associate Professor in the Department of Kinesiology, School of Public Health at the University of Maryland College Park (UMD). Dr. Roberts is also the Founder and Director of the Public Health Outcomes and Effects of the Built Environment (PHOEBE) Laboratory as well as the Co-Founder and Co-Director of NatureRx@UMD, an initiative that emphasizes the green space benefits interspersed throughout and around the UMD campus and acknowledges the ancestral lands of the Piscataway People as well as the historical slave trade legacies of the UMD campus land. Dr. Dána-Ain Davis is Professor of Urban Studies and Anthropology at Queens College, City University of New York (CUNY) and on the faculty of the PhD Program in Critical Psychology. She is the director of the Center for the Study of Women and Society at the CUNY Graduate Center. Her talk, titled “Traumatic Repercussions Black Women and Obstetric Racism” discussed how race confounds the perception that class is the root of adverse birth outcomes and the role that birth workers—midwives, doulas, and birth advocates - play in addressing Black women’s birth outcomes.
FY 22-23.topAchievements4: S-21 Renewal submission January 17th, 2023. CEMHD led the development and submission of the renewal application to the NIMHD for an additional $10,000,000 endowment to to build research and training capacity in minority health and health disparities and contribute to the diversification of the scientific workforce. Specifically, we will use the Renewal Endowment to diversify and increase the number of faculty scholars engaging in health disparities research at UAlbany while also expanding opportunities for career development and training in research strategies identified as priorities by the NIMHD. These activities will complement the activities being accomplished with the support of our 2016 Endowment, through which we are increasing the number of PhD-trained scientists and professionals from underrepresented groups with the Presidential Health Disparities Doctoral Fellowship Program. At this time (6/1/2023) the proposal is under review.
FY 22-23.topAchievements5: b. The CEMHD maintains two community task forces in Albany and Amsterdam, NY dedicated to fostering community-researcher partnerships to address health disparities. Regular members include community leaders affiliated with governmental and other organizations dedicated to health and human services and UAlbany researchers. Members work together to identify causes and possible solutions for health disparities, develop research projects, and provide guidance on research projects in these communities. Each task force convenes approximately once a month. The Albany Minority Health Task Force focuses primarily on the needs of the Black/African American community and low-income families in Albany. The Amsterdam Minority Health Task Force focuses on the needs of immigrants, individuals with limited English proficiency (particularly Spanish speakers), mothers, and the elderly in the more rural regions of Montgomery and Fulton counties of New York. HDTFs participate in the community health task forces to develop the Fellows’ organizational and operational skills and qualifications as community engaged health disparities researchers thus aiding in the acquisition of a professional position. Almost every Task Force meeting in 2022 was attended by at least one Fellow for a total of 54 showings.
FY 22-23.goal1: ​​Provide continuing support to Health Disparities Fellows in the form of stipends, tuition and fees, writing and statistics support, and conference travel support. Resume recruitment and admit 2 new Fellows to enter the program in Fall 2023.
FY 22-23.goal2: ​​Continue to support at least two community task forces to promote community engaged research and support community engagement.
FY 22-23.goal3: ​​Promote health disparities research and collaboration among University at Albany researchers and their partners through the annual President’s Forum on Health Disparities and ongoing collaboration with the Engaged Researcher group of the newly forming Institute for the Achievement of Social and Health Equity.
FY 22-23.goal4: ​​Support submission of a renewal application for a $10M NIMHD S21 Health Disparities Endowment grant (FOA anticipated in FY 2022-2023).

Fellowship admissions Fellows' satisfaction with academic support (writing and statistics)
FY 22-23.actions3: ​​Organize President’s Forum on Health Disparities, featuring a nationally recognized authority on health disparities, and interactively engaging faculty researchers and community members.  Collaborate with Engaged Researcher group on presentation of research talks by external experts on health disparities/health equity.
FY 22-23.actions4: ​CEMHD led the development of the renewal application, with successful submission of the proposal on January 17, 2023.

FY 22-23.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: Renewal of Hearst Foundations Award to support the Presidential Doctoral Fellowship Program in Health Disparities
FY 22-23.bigChallenges: CEMHD is at capacity in administering the NIMHD S21 Health Disparities Endowment grant and Presidential Fellowship programD. In 2020, CEMHD received a $1,000,000 grant from the Hearst Foundation to support doctoral studies in health disparities, which allowed significant expansion of the program’s cohort. Together, the Hearst award and the S-21 endowment are projected to support, as of Fall 2023, a transdisciplinary doctoral fellowship program for 12 doctoral students from programs across the University. Center staff are working to address administrative challenges accompanying this expansion while continuing to innovate to support the Fellows in their home departments, while ensuring that they receive the transdisciplinary training that is a signature strength of the fellowship program. As the endowment grows, and the Center is able to grow its research-related activities (e.g., pursuit of external research funding, speaker series, workshops for faculty to promote community enaged research, supporting pilot research projects), additional staff will be needed.
FY 22-23.strategicSuggestions: Funding of pilot projects that are specifically tied to the pursuit of external funding opportunities is an important strategy. Such activities should be complemented by support in grant seeking at NIH and NSF.

otherAchievements.unit: Center for Elimination of Minority Health Disparities
otherAchievements.Achievement: c.	CEMHD continues to work on increasing outreach and communication to local and larger communities through our web presence within the UAlbany Website and through social media outlets. The website hosts both publications in health disparities for our Fellows and Associates, and any upcoming events that our HDTFs and Associates are involved in. Our quarterly CEMHD Newsletter/Bulletin is emailed to stakeholders and also available on our website. The Newsletter/Bulletin showcases achievements by Associates and Fellows, and highlights accomplishments of our Amsterdam and Albany Minority Health Task Forces. We also use social media, including Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter.

FY 23-24.unit: Center for Elimination of Minority Health Disparities
FY 23-24.mission: ​​The mission of the Center for the Elimination of Minority Health Disparities (CEMHD) is to contribute to the elimination of minority health disparities in the smaller cities and towns of New York State. CEMHD’s activities focus on three major interrelated areas, in the service of contributing to the elimination of minority health disparities community engagement, fostering health disparities research, and supporting the development of new health disparities scholars.
FY 23-24.vision: ​​​​The Center for the Elimination of Minority Health Disparities (CEMHD), is a collaborative effort focusing on minority health disparities in the smaller cities and towns of New York. Home to a 2016 NIMHD S21 Health Disparities Endowment Grant, a 2009 NIMHD P20 Exploratory Center of Excellence, and a 2004 NIMHD R24 EXPORT Center, CEMHD works toward eliminating health disparities by developing capacity in faculty at the University at Albany and partnering with community groups to identify their health concerns and the sources of disparities, and strategies to alleviate them. CEMHD is a partnership among community groups, hospitals, state and county health departments, the State of New York and the University at Albany. CEMHD's focus on minorities and under-served populations in the smaller cities and towns of Upstate New York is premised upon the notion that health disparities found in these areas differ from those in the larger cities, and that the appropriate solutions will also differ. Since most of the research on minority health disparities, and the programs that have resulted from it, has focused on populations in large cities, relatively little is known about the distinct causes of poorer health among minorities in smaller cities. Therefore, another reason for our geographical emphasis is to fill in a gap in the research.

FY 23-24.goal1: ​​Provide continuing support to Health Disparities Fellows in the form of stipends, tuition and fees, writing and statistics support, and conference travel support. Resume recruitment and admit 2 new Fellows to enter the program in Fall 2023.
FY 23-24.goal2: Continue to support at least two community task forces to promote community engaged research and support community engagement.
FY 23-24.goal3: Promote health disparities research and collaboration among University at Albany researchers and their partners through the annual President’s Forum on Health Disparities and ongoing collaboration with the Engaged Researcher group of the newly forming Institute for the Achievement of Social and Health Equity.
FY 23-24.actions1: ​Progress of Fellows in meeting home department requirements and Fellowship requirements (i.e., Experiential Learning Placements, Health Disparities Certificate Program, community task force participation). Fellowship admissions Fellows' satisfaction with academic support (writing and statistics)
FY 23-24.actions3: Organize President’s Forum on Health Disparities, featuring a nationally recognized authority on health disparities, and interactively engaging faculty researchers and community members.  Collaborate with Engaged Researcher group on presentation of research talks by external experts on health disparities/health equity.
FY 23-24.metrics1: Fellows' completion of Experiential Learning Placements, progress in completing Health Disparities Certificate Program, number of community task force meetings attended; number of Fellowship applications & acceptances; Fellows' satisfaction with support.
FY 23-24.metrics2:
Number of Task Force meetings & attendance
Engagement of Task Forces with University researchers (measured through presentations in TF meetings, support of UA researcher proposals)
FY 23-24.metrics3: Timely organization and presentation of Presidents Health Disparities Forum; and participation (attendance) of all identified stakeholder groups in the Forum. Number of talks/symposia co-sponsored by CEMHD with ER group/Institute for Social and Health Equity.

FY 23-24.impactResearchExcellence2: Supports Strategic Priorities of Engagement and Service, Diversity and Inclusion, and Student Success.
FY 23-24.impactResearchExcellence3: Supports Campus Stategic Priorities of Research and Enagement Service

FY 22-23.mission: Through fundamental and applied interdisciplinary research, the mission of the Atmospheric Sciences Research Center is to expand our understanding of the physical and chemical processes that govern the atmosphere-land-water system to improve the quality of life and economic well-being of citizens across New York State, the nation and the world.
FY 22-23.vision: ​​To maintain and expand ASRC as a global leader in atmospheric and environmental sciences research and its application to the betterment of society, in an inclusive and collaborative environment that values integrity, diversity and the well-being of all.
FY 22-23.goal1: ​Maintain strengths and establish new research strengths (in wake of upcoming retirements): • Renewable Energy/Grid Resiliency • Atmospheric Chemistry (including Whiteface activity) • Climate • Urban Environment and Health • AI applications in Atmospheric Sciences • Hydrology (including water resources, flooding applications
FY 22-23.goal2: ​​Establish interdisciplinary research partnerships with College of Emergency Preparedness, Homeland Security and Cybersecurity, College of Engineering and Applied Sciences, School of Public Health and others as appropriate.
FY 22-23.goal3: ​​Develop and implement a strategy for attracting and retaining high quality and diverse faculty, staff, researchers and students to the Center.
FY 22-23.goal4: ​​Maintain and grow support for ASRC research: pre- and post-award support, IT
FY 22-23.goal5: Maintain and exploit our available facilities – including Whiteface Laboratory and NYS Mesonet).
FY 22-23.actions1:
​Through interdisciplinary collaborations pursue funding from all applicable federal, state, and private sources within these research strengths.

Seek hires in faculty, students and staff to contribute to these themes.
FY 22-23.actions2:
​
​Identify NYS agencies we should target for partnerships/funding and get to know key people within the agency

Establish a mechanism for regular sharing of grant opportunities for interdisciplinary research including seed funding.

Have Clark Hill conduct a seminar on federal opportunities (especially large, multidisciplinary, multi-org).
FY 22-23.actions3: ​​Develop succession plan for impending faculty retirements, including new EIP hire.  Enhance recruitment efforts for attracting a strong and diverse cohort of graduate students  Establish and implement a networking strategy for UG and Grad students in ETEC, highlighting the research and opportunities in ASRC  Hire a communications person to help ASRC keep content current on all outlets (Web, social media, print pieces); could be a freelancer
FY 22-23.actions4:
​
​Advocate for the Research Facilitator position to be filled in the wake of the upcoming retirement of Cathy Lott in 2022.

Conduct needs analysis for ASRC IT support.

Identify how ASRC will invest its ICR return in operational vs. strategic needs.
FY 22-23.actions5:
​Develop a support plan for Whiteface observatory in collaboration with DEC and other ASRC faculty who do field work at the observatory.

Establish a mechanism for monitoring and approving budgets for NYS Mesonet – as well as securing Federal and State funds to support it.

FY 23-24.mission: ​​Through fundamental and applied interdisciplinary research, the mission of the Atmospheric Sciences Research Center is to expand our understanding of the physical and chemical processes that govern the atmosphere-land-water system to improve the quality of life and economic well-being of citizens across New York State, the nation and the world.
FY 23-24.vision: ​​To maintain and expand ASRC as a global leader in atmospheric and environmental sciences research and its application to the betterment of society, in an inclusive and collaborative environment that values integrity, diversity and the well-being of all.
FY 23-24.annualBudget: ​​People: ASRC’s 14 faculty and 7 staff (including one full-time staff person at Whiteface Mountain) are supported by UAlbany. Over the past five years, ASRC’s payroll expenditures totaled $10,706,372 – an average of $2,141,274 per year. One full-time research facilitator and one part-time IT support person are supported by the VPR. Post-docs, research scientists, visiting scholars, graduate students, and undergraduate students are primarily paid from research grants; some are supported from start-up funds provided to SUNY2020 faculty. Most ASRC faculty are on 9-month academic year appointments and are paid summer salary from research grants or start-up funds. OTPS: ASRC’s operations, including operations at the UAlbany location and at Whiteface Mountain, are covered by IFR revenue recovered from sponsored programs. Over the past five years, ASRC’s OTPS expenditures at the Albany location have totaled $202,696, an average of $40,539 per year. Not counting annual telephone charges of almost $19,000 per year, OTPS expenses at ASRC average about $21,539 per year. The Whiteface location’s OTPS expenditures over five years total $77,606, an average of $15,521 per year. One faculty member had a legacy IFR account that covered some OTPS expenses such as Verizon Wireless. Strategic Investment: In the past, ASRC has received overhead recovery from the VPR to be used to grow research activity at ASRC. We have about $70,900 remaining in cash to spend on the state-side. On the RF side there is a legacy overhead recovery account primarily used in support of our RF p-card program as the initial source to pay the Bank of America bill monthly; expenses are then moved to the appropriate sponsored award through a reconciliation process. Events: ASRC has both UAlbany Foundation funds in the Ray Falconer Endowment and UAS (Auxiliary Services) funds to support lectures and colloquies.
